Comment: If the reports on the retaliatory tariffs are correct, than this is likely China offering a miniscule concession to begin the process of de-escalation. It's pretty standard diplomacy in these situations and, thus, virtually a guarantee that Trump had nothing to do with it.       See the "Checkpoint Charlie" incident in Berlin 1961, where American and Soviet tanks stood barrel to barrel at a bridge for over a day. Eventually, the Soviets ceded something ludicrous (an inch or something) and the US went back another inch. Each side used the initial concession as justification for more further and more dramatic concessions until the bridge was vacated.   As to why China might be doing it--there are dueling fantasies on Reddit that either Trump has all the cards or China has all the cards and, the reality is, neither of them have any cards and the bureaucrats and diplomats who do the day-to-day work of making the world work know that. Neoliberal foreign policy is built on the idea that, fundamentally, we'll be so involved in each other's economies that it would disincentivize open conflict. IF, and that's a big IF, it's true than that's likely what we're seeing in action.
